posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked:
What originally started as a personal challenge of cadding a robot for REEFSCAPE in 24 hours, quickly turned into cadding a robot in a more reasonable amount of time. I was inspired by @howlongismyname doing the same thing last year and this year and took it as a personal goal to cad a robot as quickly as I could.

And so: I present my 2025 REEFSCAPE Robot: WISP Onshape Link

WISP 7009×4955 10.5 MB

WISP 7009×4955 10.5 MB

WISP 7009×4955 10.5 MB

WISP 7009×4955 10.5 MB

Archetype 7009×4955 4.56 MB

Archetype 7009×4955 4.56 MB

Archetype 7009×4955 4.56 MB

Archetype 7009×4955 4.56 MB

Front mount elevator with a funnel to intake coral from hp

Front mount elevator with a funnel to intake coral from hp

Laterator to extend the coral mech to the reef

Laterator to extend the coral mech to the reef

Algae intake on the back

Algae intake on the back

Deep climb integrated into the algae intake

Deep climb integrated into the algae intake

110lbs dry weight, 140lbs fully loaded

110lbs dry weight, 140lbs fully loaded

Mk4i Swerve

Mk4i Swerve

11’’ COG Height

11’’ COG Height

Drop chassis with 3/16" ground clearance

Drop chassis with 3/16" ground clearance

16 Motors

16 Motors

Designed with manufacturing in mind, the only hard-to-make parts are the bent polycarb and the tube support blocks on the climber.

Designed with manufacturing in mind, the only hard-to-make parts are the bent polycarb and the tube support blocks on the climber.

Keeps cost down, this robot uses only NEO motors and common COTS items

Keeps cost down, this robot uses only NEO motors and common COTS items

Uses a common plate thickness, Every aluminum plate is 1/8 thick except for the bumper brackets

Uses a common plate thickness, Every aluminum plate is 1/8 thick except for the bumper brackets

Counterbalanced elevator with Constant force springs: Increases cycle times and reduces needed gearing on the drive motors

Counterbalanced elevator with Constant force springs: Increases cycle times and reduces needed gearing on the drive motors

L1 to L4 coral, theoretical cycle times < 1 second (after drivebase lines up)

L1 to L4 coral, theoretical cycle times < 1 second (after drivebase lines up)

Removes algae from the reef with an integrated roller on the end effector

Removes algae from the reef with an integrated roller on the end effector

Ground intake algae to score in the proccessor

Ground intake algae to score in the proccessor

Human player intake Coral, Funnel means you don’t have to line up

Human player intake Coral, Funnel means you don’t have to line up

Goal: Maximize points earned

Cycle L1-4 Coral as fast as possible

Goal: Maximize Rp earned via coral and algae scoring

Cycle L1-4 Coral while removing all algae from the reef

Cycle L1-4 Coral while removing all algae from the reef

Once the reef is free of algae you can switch to algae cleanup or continue cycling coral

Once the reef is free of algae you can switch to algae cleanup or continue cycling coral

Goal: Guarantee Barge RP without relying on teammates to climb

Continue cycling coral or algae as long as possible

Continue cycling coral or algae as long as possible

Deep climb at the last possible moment, the intake geometry means it’s easy to line up

Deep climb at the last possible moment, the intake geometry means it’s easy to line up

When kickoff happened I immediately started thinking about what the most effective ways to play the game would be and considered all aspects of the game I decided that my ideal robot would be able to:

ground algae

processor algae

l1-4 Coral

HP intake coral

Deep climb

Notable things that I deemed unimportant or unnecessary:

net algae - avoid the extra complexity to lift or shoot the balls

ground coral - 2 hp stations per side mean its unlikely that ground pickup is the only option

shallow climb - deep climb is easier and worth more points

controlled reef algae - removing algae from the reef without controlling it means the end effector can be far simpler

These strategic choices allowed for a competitive robot without sacrificing performance for unneeded complexity and drove the design of my robot. I’m not trying to make the best robot but I am trying to make a robot that i think would be fun to drive. a complex robot that is impossible to drive isn’t fun for anyone involved.

WISP has 7 Major subsystems.

30x30 Mk4i Square with a 1/8" bellypan

combining the passive writst, laterator, elevator, and the end effector allows for efficient coral scoring cycles, while the algae mechanism scoops up algae in the meantime.

Step 1: The robot is in starting configuration Starting Config 7009×4955 6.5 MB Step 2: The Algae mechanism deploys to make way for the laterator as the elevator starts going up Intake Deploys 7009×4955 6.54 MB Step 3: The elevator goes up to the desired scoring level 1-4 Elevator Goes Up 4956×7009 3.32 MB Step 4: The laterator extends to line up the coral with the reef lateratorExtends 4956×7009 3.27 MB Step 5: The elevator starts coming down, and the algae catches on the reef Elevator Comes Down 7009×4955 3.04 MB Step 6: The elevator keeps going down, the passive wrist allows the coral to line up right onto the reef Wrist In Full Motion 7009×4955 2.87 MB Step 7: The elevator keeps going down and the laterator starts retracting, Pulling the coral out of the gripper. Scored The Coral 7009×4955 3.07 MB Step 8: The laterator fully retracts, the passive wrist flops back down to the neutral position laterator Retracted 7009×4955 3.01 MB Step 9: The coral has been scored and the robot is now ready to intake a new one from the HP station

throughout the time designing WISP, I faced some challenges, mainly integrating all the mechanisms while still leaving room for deep climb and the laterator. as well as trying to make weight.

if I were to do this again I would spend more time picking an archetype, as I don’t believe that combining the algae and climber mechanisms was the wisest choice.

Things to add:

Vision system

Cable chain on the elevator Added

Hardstops on the wrist

Better breaker placement

Battery wires

I hope that by sharing this I inspire you this season! If you have any questions or comments, please feel free to post here or contact me directly.

shoutout to @AntPoison for helping with the writing and formatting

What the…

This is extremely impressive and I have no idea how its in weight.

posts.name: Wolly :)
posts.cooked: Neat! Interesting architecture, especially the algae intake integrated with the climber. Could you show some more angles of the climber interacting with the cage? Also maybe some shots of scoring coral on the reef - I see the advantage of the cantilevered rollers in scoring but want to see it on L2/L3.

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: ive edited the post to include a section showing the robot doing various activities, if theres any other sections i should include let me know.

posts.cooked: LEGOMONSTER W ONCE AGAIN. Such a beautiful design in my opinion. Well done bro, and congratulations on completing it!
